importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the protest and police incident in Dublin, indicating a significant public safety and political event.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The protest and attack occurred in the evening, suggesting a large-scale public gathering during a time of heightened tension and visibility.

keyTakeAways: Irish police were attacked with missiles and fireworks at a protest outside the Citywest Hotel in Saggart, Dublin.
A police van was set on fire, indicating a violent escalation of the protest.
Thousands of people gathered at the protest, highlighting public mobilization over asylum seeker issues.
Taoiseach Micheál Martin condemned the attacks on police as unjustifiable and praised the courage of the Gardaí.
Justice Minister Jim O'Callaghan called the violence 'unacceptable' and affirmed a forceful police response and legal action against perpetrators.
Presidential candidates Heather Humphreys and Catherine Connolly expressed concern, emphasizing the incident reflects poorly on national unity and values.
The incident underscores growing social and political divisions around asylum policies in Ireland.

namedEntities.name: Dublin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the protest and the incident, central to the geographical context of the event.

namedEntities.name: Citywest Hotel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A hotel used to house asylum seekers in Saggart, Dublin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The focal point of the protest and the target of the demonstrators' actions.

namedEntities.name: Saggart
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific location of the hotel and protest, indicating a local community affected by the unrest.

namedEntities.name: Taoiseach Micheál Martin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly condemned the violence against police and recognized the bravery of the Gardaí, signaling national leadership response.

namedEntities.name: Jim O'Callaghan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He declared the violence unacceptable and committed to a forceful police and legal response, showing government enforcement action.

namedEntities.name: Heather Humphreys
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the violence as 'absolutely awful' and emphasized it contradicts national values, reflecting political public opinion.

namedEntities.name: Catherine Connolly
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She described the scenes as 'very upsetting' and warned of emerging societal divisions, showing political awareness of social tensions.

namedEntities.name: Gardaí
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The police force was directly targeted, including being attacked and having a van set on fire, illustrating the severity of the confrontation.

namedEntities.name: RTÉ
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported that several thousand people gathered, providing independent verification of the scale of the protest.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A protest outside the Citywest Hotel in Saggart, Dublin, escalated into violence when Irish police were attacked with missiles and fireworks, and a police van was set on fire. Thousands gathered, prompting the Taoiseach Micheál Martin and Justice Minister Jim O'Callaghan to condemn the attacks as unjustifiable and unacceptable, with both pledging strong responses. Presidential candidates Heather Humphreys and Catherine Connolly expressed concern, highlighting the incident as a sign of deepening societal divisions over asylum policies. The event underscores significant public unrest and tensions in Ireland regarding asylum seeker housing and national values.
title: Dublin: Police van set on fire at protest outside asylum seeker hotel
